review.title: Manipulation of Nanson's and Baldwin's Rules
review.abstract: Nanson's and Baldwin's voting rules select a winner by successively eliminating candidates with low Borda scores. We show that these rules have a number of desirable computational properties. In particular, with unweighted votes, it is NP-hard to manipulate either rule with one manipulator, whilst with weighted votes, it is NP-hard to manipulate either rule with a small number of candidates and a coalition of manipulators. As only a couple of other voting rules are known to be NP-hard to manipulate with a single manipulator, Nanson's and Baldwin's rules appear to be particularly resistant to manipulation from a theoretical perspective. We also propose a number of approximation methods for manipulating these two rules. Experiments demonstrate that both rules are often difficult to manipulate in practice. These results suggest that elimination style voting rules deserve further study.

sections.heading: Introduction
sections.text: How do we decide whether we have elicited enough votes from the agents to announce the result? While there has been a very active research community in Melbourne that has investigated these kinds of questions for well-known electoral rules such as plurality and Borda, there are other, less well-known rules that might merit attention. Specifically, we are putting forward two historical electoral rules that stem from Nanson and Baldwin related to Borda elections. There are several reasons to consider these two rules. First, they have features that might appeal to the two opposing camps that support Borda and Condorcet. Specifically, both rules are consistent with Condorcet, since they elect the candidate who beats everyone else in paired elections. Secondly, both rules are elimination procedures in which the candidates are successively removed. Other elimination procedures such as STV and plurality in runoff elections are consistent because they elect the candidate who beats everyone else.

sections.heading: Nanson’s and Baldwin’s Rules
sections.text: The Borda Rule has several good features, such as it is monotonous, since increasing the score for a candidate only contributes to his winning. Moreover, it never votes for the Condorcet loser (a candidate who loses to everyone else in a head-to-head election), whereas the rules of Nanson and Baldwin always choose the Condorcet winner when there is one. Nanson and Baldwin's rules are derived from the Borda Rule. Nanson's rule eliminates all candidates with less than the average Borda score (Nanson 1882), and then repeats the rule with the reduced number of candidates until there is a single candidate. A closely related electoral rule proposed by Baldwin eliminates the candidate with the lowest Borda score until a candidate remains (Baldwin 1926). The two rules are closely linked and sometimes even confused.

sections.heading: Approximation Methods
sections.text: One way to deal with a target number of manipulators is to treat this number as an approximation problem, in which we try to minimize the number of manipulators. We have therefore considered five approximation methods that are derived either from the methods used with Borda, or that are specifically designed for eliminating candidates who have the rules of Borda's and Baldwin's rulesse.REVERSE was used to manipulate the Borda rule (Zuckerman, Procaccia, Procaccia and Rosenschein 2009).LARGESTFIT: This method was proposed for the Borda rule (Davies et al). Unlike REVERSE, which constructs votes from one, we construct votes in any order, we construct votes in any order that puts the next largest Borda score in the "best" vote available.

sections.heading: Experimental Results
sections.text: To test the difficulty of calculating manipulations in practice and the effectiveness of these approximation methods, we conducted some experiments with a similar setup (Walsh 2010). We generated either uniform random votes or votes from a Polya Eggenberger urns model. In the urns model, votes are drawn randomly and are put back into the ballot box along with other votes of the same type. This captures different degrees of social homogeneity. We have a = m! so there is a 50% chance that the second vote is the same as the first. Our first experiments were conducted with 3000 candidates and 5 non-tampering voters.

sections.heading: Other Related Work
sections.text: Bag, Sabourian, & Winter (2009) demonstrate that a class of voting rules that provides for repeated ballots and eliminates one candidate in each round is consistent with Condorcet. They illustrate this class with the weakest-link rule, in which the candidate with the fewest ballots in each round is eliminated. Geller (2005) proposed a variant of a single transferable vote in which candidates are successively eliminated on the basis of their original Borda value. Unlike the rules of Nanson and Baldwin, this method does not recalculate the Borda value on the basis of the new reduced number of candidates; for each uniform Condorcet rule (and thus for the rule of Nanson and Baldwin), Brandt et al. (2010) showed that many types of control and manipulation are polynomic when votes are counted individually.

sections.heading: Conclusions
sections.text: With unweighted votes, we have proven that the rules of Nanson and Baldwin are difficult to manipulate with just one manipulator, but with weighted votes, we have proven that the rules of Nanson are difficult to manipulate with only a small number of candidates and a coalition of manipulators. We have also proposed a number of approaches to manipulating the rules of Nanson and Baldwin. Our experiments suggest that both rules are difficult to manipulate in practice. There are many other interesting open questions arising from these results. For example, are there other elimination-style voting rules that are difficult to manipulate mathematically?
